metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of eddy covariance observations at the Yingke oasis station
metadata.description:
The dataset of eddy covariance observations was obtained at the Yingke Oasis station from 27 Dec. 2007 to 31 Dec. 2009. The observation site is located in an irrigation farmland in Yingke (E100°24′37.2″/N38°51′25.7″, 1519.1m), Zhangye city, Gansu province. The experimental area, situated in the middle stream Heihe river basin and with windbreaks space of 500m from east to west and 300m from south to north, is an ideal choice for its flat and open terrain. 
     The original observation items included the latitudinal wind speed Ux (m/s), the latitudinal wind speed Uy (m/s), the longitudinal wind speed Uz (m/s), the ultrasonic temperature Ts (°C), co2 consistency (mg/m^3), h2o consistency (g/m^3), air pressure (KPa) and the abnormal ultrasonic signal (diag_csat). The instrument mount was 2.81m, the ultrasound direction was at an azimuth angle of 0°, the distance between Li7500 and CSAT3 was 30cm and the sampling frequency was 10HZ/s.
     The dataset was distributed at three levels: Level0 were the raw data acquired by instruments; Level1, including the sensible heat flux (Hs), the latent heat flux (LE_wpl), and co2 flux (Fc_wpl), were real-time eddy covariance output data and stored in .csv month by month; Level2 were processed data in a 30-minute cycle after outliers elimination, coordinates rotation, frequency response correction, WPL correction and initial quality control. The data files were named as follows: station name +data level+data acquisition date. As for detailed information, please refer to Meteorological and Hydrological Flux Data Guide and Eddy Covariance Observation Manual.

background: Land surface heat fluxes are essential measures of the strengths of land-atmosphere interactions involving energy, heat and water. Correct parameterization of these fluxes in climate models is critical. Despite their importance, state-of-the-art observation techniques cannot provide representative areal averages of these fluxes comparable to the model grid. These alternative approaches use (satellite) observables of the land surface conditions.
research objective: In this study, the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) algorithm was evaluated in a cold and arid environment, using land surface parameters derived from Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER) data.
methods: Field observations and estimates from SEBS were compared in terms of net radiation flux (Rn), soil heat flux (G0), sensible heat flux (H) and latent heat flux (λE) over a heterogeneous land surface. As a case study, this methodology was applied to the experimental area of the Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (W A TER) project, located on the mid-to-upstream sections of the Heihe River in northwest China. ASTER data acquired between 3 May and 4 June 2008, under clear-sky conditions were used to determine the surface fluxes. Ground-based measurements of land surface heat fluxes were compared with values derived from the ASTER data.
dataset: ASTER data acquired between 3 May and 4 June 2008, under clear-sky conditions were used to determine the surface fluxes.
findings: The results showed the following: The derived net radiation flux over the study area was very close to the field measurements. The latent heat flux is obtained by calculations involving the evaporative fraction, and these calculations are the essence of SEBS. On the basis of this particular study, SEBS can be used to estimate turbulent heat fluxes with acceptable accuracy in areas where there is partial vegetation cover.

background: Land surface Evapotranspiration (ET) is one of the most important components in the water cycle between the earth and atmosphere, and plays a very important role in the atmosphere, hydrosphere, and biosphere of the planet. Studies (Dickinson, 1984; Avissar, 1998) on climate models and general circulation models (GCMs) have found that the climate is sensitive to the change of land surface evapotranspiration. At present, remote sensing may be the only efficient technical way that can be used to monitor surface evapotranspiration on the regional scale (Mu et al., 2007; Stisen et al., 2008). Generally, surface evapotranspiration (i.e. latent heat flux LE) is estimated as the residual term of surface energy balance equation. The turbulent heat fluxes models to estimate the sensible heat flux can be categorized into two groups, single-source models and dual-source models, according to whether or not the model separates the foliage and the substrate soil. Many authors (Blyth et al., 1995; Verhoef et al., 1997; Troufleau et al., 1997; Kustas et al., 1999; Massman, 1999) have examined the features of the kB −1 parameter. This problem can be circumvented to some extent by using the dual-source models. In this type of models, the heat fluxes of the components (foliage and soil) are simulated individually, and the aerodynamic temperature is analytically expressed in terms of the component temperatures and a set of resistances, as described in the two-layer model proposed by Shuttleworth and Wallace (1985) and revised by Shuttleworth and Gurney (1990).
research objective: In this study, we have developed a physics-based Two-layer Surface Energy Balance Parameterization Scheme (TSEBPS) for estimation of land surface heat fluxes.
challenges: Even though the advantage of the dual-source models in physics has been recognized by the scientific community, the most widely used methods in applications are still based on the assumption of the single source of the surface heat fluxes. This results from such a fact that the use of the two-layer model for operational purpose requires component surface temperatures (i.e. soil and vegetation), which is still not available from regular observations and retrieval of the most space-borne remote sensors.
methods: In this study, we have developed a physics-based Two-layer Surface Energy Balance Parameterization Scheme (TSEBPS) for estimation of land surface heat fluxes. We combined the two-layer model developed by Shuttleworth and Wallace (1985) with techniques of handling limiting cases as shown in Su (2002) and Norman et al. (1995) to derive the Component Temperature Difference (CTD) under several extreme soil moisture states. Additionally, a directional thermal radiative transfer model is used to simulate the radiative surface temperature at these states. Then an index is developed using the observed surface temperature and the simulated temperature at the extreme states. This index is then used to calculate the actual sensible and latent heat fluxes of the foliage and soil surface.
dataset: Two experimental data sets are used to assess the reliabilities of TSEBPS.
findings: Based on these case studies, TSEBPS has proven to be capable of estimating heat fluxes at vegetation surfaces with acceptable accuracy. The uncertainties in the estimated heat fluxes are comparable to in-situ measurement uncertainties.

background: Gross primary production (GPP) is defined as the overall rate of fixation of carbon through the process of vegetation photosynthesis. It is used to quantify the amount of biomass produced within an ecosystem over a unit of time, regardless of the amount of respiration. The seasonal difference of GPP and ecosystem respiration (Re) determines the net ecosystem exchange (NEE) of CO2 between the atmosphere and forest ecosystems and is important for understanding global carbon cycle climate change research. The eddy covariance (EC) technique is one of the best micrometeorological methods for the estimation of CO2, water, and energy exchange between the atmosphere and terrestrial ecosystems. Satellite remote sensing provides consistent and systematic land surface observations and has played an increasing role in characterizing vegetation structure and estimating GPP. The fundamental methodology of GPP estimation is based on Monteith’s equation: GPP ¼ LUE /C2 fAPAR /C2 PAR, where LUE is the light use efficiency, often in units of mol CO2 per mol photosynthetic photon flux density (mol CO2 mol−1 PPFD), and fAPAR represents the fraction of absorbed photosynthetically active radiation (PAR). Many models and methods using the LUE basis have been proposed for GPP estimation from ground measurements and satellite remote sensing data.
research objective: In this study, the daily MODIS surface reflectance product was selected for midday GPP estimation because MODIS can provide daily coverage of the study sites with an acceptable ground resolution and the required spectral characteristics. On the basis of previous research, we selected some VIs that were proved to have the potential to estimate LUE (mol CO2 mol−1 PPFD) and fAPAR and proposed a method to estimate GPP (mg CO2 m−2 s−1) with the MODIS data. The study should be helpful for future GPP models driven by all remote‐sensing inputs.
challenges: However, besides the difficulty of partitioning the respiration of ecosystems into autotrophic respiration and heterotrophic respiration, the EC only provides integrated CO2 flux measurements over footprints with sizes and shapes that vary with the tower height, canopy physical characteristics, and wind velocity. The limitation of LUE models, however, is that they require meteorological inputs that are often not available at sufficiently detailed temporal and spatial scales, resulting in substantial errors in the outputs. Estimates of daytime Re from the nighttime RE‐T relation are associated with considerable uncertainties such as the overestimation of daytime respiration due to the extrapolation of nighttime respiration fluxes.
methods: In this study, we evaluated the broadband MODIS VIs for the LUE and fAPAR estimation and tried to understand the mechanism of our GPP estimation methodology. When we estimated GPP using the expression VI × VI × PAR, the determination coefficients R2 largely improved (R2 = 0.81 to 0.91), indicating that GPP can be well estimated with MODIS.
dataset: The study sites were located outside the city of Zhangye, Gansu Province, in western China. All measurements were taken from 10 June to 13 July 2008. The maize was planted in early May 2008 in the typical solonetzic soil of western China with relatively sufficient nutrition and water supplies. To form a suite of data, the product (MOD 09, 500 m) of the Terra MODIS surface‐reflectance atmospheric correction algorithm from 13 June to 10 July 2008 was downloaded to estimate the midday GPP at the satellite overpass time. After selection, 16 cloud‐free days of data were used to develop our method for GPP estimation.
findings: EVI × EVI × PAR provided the best estimation of GPP with the highest R2 of 0.91 because EVI was found to be the best indicator of both LUE and fAPAR (R2 of 0.87 and 0.76, respectively).

background: Radar remote sensing has demonstrated its applicability to the retrieval of basin-scale soil moisture. The mechanism of radar backscattering from soils is complicated and strongly influenced by surface roughness. Surface soil moisture (mv) is important in agronomic, hydrological, and meteorological processes at all spatial scales. It plays a key role in water stress detection and irrigation management, especially for arid and semi-arid regions. It is well known that space-borne microwave radiometers and scatterometers possess the advantage of high revisit capacity but deficient in coarse spatial resolution. On the contrary, synthetic aperture radar (SAR) sensors have the capability to provide finer spatial resolution, on the order of tens of meters, meeting most spatial requirements for watershed management and hydrological applications. Radar systems emit pulses and receive echoes backscattered from the illuminated areas. The intensity value of each pixel is proportional to the radar backscattering coefficient (σ0), which depends on several factors, including the instrument’s technical specifications (frequency and polarization), terrain, dielectric characteristics (εr; strongly related to the soil water content) and the geometrical structure (roughness) of the target surface. The IEM unites the KA and the SPM and was verified by laboratory measurements of bistatic scattering from surfaces with small, intermediate and large scale roughness. The advanced IEM (AIEM) improves the calculation accuracy of scattering coefficient by keeping the absolute phase term in Greens function which was neglected by IEM. In the IEM and AIEM, surface roughness is an essential input.
research objective: This study aims to simultaneously obtain surface roughness parameters (standard deviation of surface height σ and correlation length cl) along with soil moisture from multi-angular ASAR images by using a two-step retrieval scheme based on the AIEM.
challenges: The key challenge is the presence of vegetation cover, which significantly impacts the estimates of surface roughness and soil moisture. Unfortunately, field measuring surface roughness is very time-consuming and almost impractical at the regional scale. Moreover, appreciable inaccuracies may occur due to various deployments of instrumentation, sampling strategy, and the ambiguous scale effect during field campaigns and data post-processing.
methods: The method firstly used a semi-empirical relationship that relates the roughness slope, Zs (Zs = σ2 /cl) and the difference in backscattering coefficient (Δσ) from two ASAR images acquired with different incidence angles. Then, the deduced roughness parameters were used for the retrieval of soil moisture in association with the AIEM. An evaluation of the proposed method was performed in an experimental area in the middle stream of the Heihe River Basin, where the Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (WATER) was taken place.
findings: It is demonstrated that the proposed method is feasible to achieve reliable estimation of soil water content.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that integrates both ground-based measurements and satellite remote sensing for estimating land surface heat fluxes?
Example.Answer: Field observations and estimates from the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) algorithm were compared in terms of net radiation flux, soil heat flux, sensible heat flux, and latent heat flux over a heterogeneous land surface using ASTER data acquired under clear-sky conditions.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered in using dual-source models for estimating land surface heat fluxes?
Example.Answer: A challenge in using dual-source models is the requirement for component surface temperatures, which are not regularly available from standard remote sensing observations, making it difficult to apply these models operationally.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how surface roughness parameters and soil moisture are simultaneously obtained from remote sensing data?
Example.Answer: Surface roughness parameters and soil moisture are obtained using a two-step retrieval scheme based on the AIEM, involving a semi-empirical relationship relating roughness slope and the difference in backscattering coefficient from multi-angular ASAR images.

Definition.Question: What is the purpose of using the eddy covariance technique in data collection for land-atmosphere interaction studies?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance (EC) technique is used for the estimation of CO2, water, and energy exchange between the atmosphere and terrestrial ecosystems. It is one of the best micrometeorological methods for understanding these exchanges, which are crucial for studying the global carbon cycle and climate change.

Definition.Question: How does the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) algorithm contribute to the estimation of land surface heat fluxes, and what parameters are involved?
Definition.Answer: The Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) algorithm is used to estimate turbulent heat fluxes by evaluating net radiation flux, soil heat flux, sensible heat flux, and latent heat flux over a land surface. The algorithm utilizes land surface parameters derived from satellite data, such as ASTER, to perform these estimations with acceptable accuracy, particularly in areas with partial vegetation cover.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with retrieving soil moisture and surface roughness parameters using radar remote sensing, and what methods are used to address them?
Definition.Answer: Radar remote sensing retrieval of soil moisture and surface roughness parameters is challenged by vegetation cover, which affects the accuracy of estimates. Methods to address these challenges include using a two-step retrieval scheme based on the Advanced Integral Equation Model (AIEM) and employing a semi-empirical relationship to deduce roughness parameters from multi-angular ASAR images.

Comparison.Question: How do the methods for estimating turbulence heat fluxes using the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) algorithm compare to the Two-layer Surface Energy Balance Parameterization Scheme (TSEBPS) in terms of accuracy and data requirements?
Comparison.Answer: The SEBS algorithm was evaluated over a heterogeneous land surface using field observations and ASTER data, while TSEBPS relies on a physics-based two-layer model to estimate land surface heat fluxes. SEBS can estimate turbulent heat fluxes with acceptable accuracy in areas with partial vegetation cover, whereas TSEBPS has proven capable of estimating heat fluxes at vegetation surfaces with uncertainties comparable to in-situ measurement uncertainties. SEBS primarily used satellite data, whereas TSEBPS required component surface temperatures not typically available from regular observations.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the data collection methods for measuring CO2 fluxes using the eddy covariance (EC) technique differ from those used for estimating evapotranspiration (ET) at the regional scale using remote sensing?
Comparison.Answer: The EC technique provides integrated CO2 flux measurements over specific footprints, making it a direct method for estimating CO2 exchange between the atmosphere and terrestrial ecosystems. It involves micrometeorological measurements that are spatially constrained by the footprint's size and shape. In contrast, estimating ET using remote sensing is an indirect method that often uses satellite data to monitor surface conditions over larger regions. Remote sensing methods for ET often involve models that require meteorological inputs and are challenged by the need for high temporal and spatial resolution data.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies could be implemented to address the challenges of accurately estimating surface heat fluxes in regions with heterogeneous land surfaces using remote sensing data?
Interpretation.Answer: In regions with heterogeneous land surfaces, methodologies such as the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) algorithm can be evaluated using satellite observables like ASTER data to estimate heat fluxes. Comparison with field observations helps ensure accuracy, particularly when dealing with partial vegetation cover.

Interpretation.Question: What are the possible techniques for integrating soil moisture and surface roughness measurements from radar remote sensing into hydrological and agronomic models for better water management?
Interpretation.Answer: Radar remote sensing, particularly multi-angular ASAR images, can be used to simultaneously retrieve soil moisture and surface roughness parameters. By applying a two-step retrieval scheme based on the AIEM, these measurements can be effectively integrated into hydrological and agronomic models for improved water management.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to errors in estimating land surface heat fluxes using remote sensing techniques, particularly in cold and arid environments?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Factors leading to errors include the inability of state-of-the-art observation techniques to provide representative areal averages of fluxes, the limitations of remote sensing data in capturing the necessary spatial and temporal details, and the challenges in parameterizing these fluxes accurately in climate models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to use dual-source models for estimating land surface heat fluxes operationally?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenge arises from the requirement for component surface temperatures (soil and vegetation), which are not readily available from regular observations and most space-borne remote sensors. This lack of data makes it difficult to implement dual-source models for operational purposes despite their recognized advantages.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the causes of inaccuracies in estimating surface roughness and soil moisture from radar remote sensing data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The primary causes include the impact of vegetation cover on estimates, the time-consuming nature of field measuring surface roughness, and potential inaccuracies due to varying instrumentation deployments, sampling strategies, and scale effects during field campaigns and data post-processing.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using dual-source models for estimating land surface heat fluxes compared to single-source models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using dual-source models allows for the separate simulation of heat fluxes from foliage and soil, which can address the limitations of single-source models that assume a single source of surface heat fluxes. This approach can improve the accuracy of flux estimations, especially when component surface temperatures are available, as it considers the distinct thermal properties and resistances of soil and vegetation.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the application of the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) algorithm in cold and arid environments affect the estimation of turbulent heat fluxes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Applying the SEBS algorithm in cold and arid environments has shown that it can estimate turbulent heat fluxes with acceptable accuracy, particularly in areas with partial vegetation cover. The algorithm's calculations involving the evaporative fraction are crucial for accurately determining latent heat flux, which aligns well with field measurements when surface parameters are derived from satellite data.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a physics-based Two-layer Surface Energy Balance Parameterization Scheme (TSEBPS) for estimating land surface heat fluxes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The development of a physics-based Two-layer Surface Energy Balance Parameterization Scheme (TSEBPS) is important to accurately estimate heat fluxes at vegetation surfaces, overcoming limitations of single-source models by simulating foliage and soil heat fluxes separately.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intention behind using radar remote sensing for the retrieval of basin-scale soil moisture, especially in arid and semi-arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to leverage radar remote sensing's capability for finer spatial resolution to obtain reliable estimates of soil moisture, which is critical for water stress detection and irrigation management, particularly in arid and semi-arid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are used to ensure the accuracy and reliability of eddy covariance flux data collected from agricultural fields in arid environments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection involves observing horizontal and vertical wind speeds, temperature, CO2, and water vapor concentrations at a sampling frequency of 10Hz. The data is processed in three levels: Level0 retains raw data, Level1 provides flux data through real-time processing with Campbell software, and Level2 includes post-processing steps like outlier removal, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, WPL correction, and initial quality control.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) algorithm be effectively applied in cold and arid regions using remote sensing data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The SEBS algorithm is used to estimate turbulent heat fluxes by comparing field observations with estimates derived from Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER) data. This involves determining net radiation, soil heat flux, sensible heat flux, and latent heat flux over heterogeneous surfaces, ensuring close alignment with field measurements.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the methodological steps involved in using radar remote sensing to retrieve soil moisture and surface roughness over a basin-scale area?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The retrieval involves using a two-step scheme based on the advanced integral equation model (AIEM) with multi-angular ASAR images. Initially, a semi-empirical relationship links roughness slope to backscattering coefficient differences from images at different incidence angles. Then, deduced roughness parameters facilitate soil moisture retrieval, accommodating vegetation impacts.

Enablement.Question: What methods or technologies enable the accurate measurement of surface heat fluxes in heterogeneous land surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: Field observations combined with the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS) algorithm, using parameters derived from ASTER data, enable the accurate measurement of surface heat fluxes over heterogeneous land surfaces.

Enablement.Question: How do remote sensing technologies facilitate the estimation of land surface evapotranspiration on a regional scale?
Enablement.Answer: Remote sensing technologies facilitate the estimation of land surface evapotranspiration by using satellite observables and models such as the Two-layer Surface Energy Balance Parameterization Scheme (TSEBPS) to estimate sensible and latent heat fluxes from vegetation and soil surfaces.

Enablement.Question: What conditions enable the retrieval of reliable soil moisture measurements using radar remote sensing techniques?
Enablement.Answer: The retrieval of reliable soil moisture measurements using radar remote sensing techniques is enabled by the use of multi-angular ASAR images and the AIEM model, which together allow for the simultaneous estimation of surface roughness parameters and soil moisture, despite challenges posed by vegetation cover.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection methods using satellite remote sensing not provide representative areal averages of land surface heat fluxes comparable to model grids?
Expectation.Answer: Despite the importance of land surface heat fluxes, state-of-the-art observation techniques, including satellite remote sensing, struggle to provide representative areal averages comparable to model grids due to the complexity of land-atmosphere interactions and the limitations in spatial resolution that satellites can achieve.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise when using dual-source models for estimating land surface heat fluxes, and why are they less commonly used than single-source models?
Expectation.Answer: Dual-source models require component surface temperatures of soil and vegetation, which are often unavailable from regular observations and most space-borne remote sensors, making them less commonly used. These models are recognized for their physical advantages, but practical implementation is challenging due to the lack of necessary data inputs.

Expectation.Question: Why might radar remote sensing techniques face difficulties in estimating soil moisture and surface roughness in regions with vegetation cover?
Expectation.Answer: The presence of vegetation cover significantly impacts the estimates of surface roughness and soil moisture, posing challenges for radar remote sensing techniques. Vegetation can obscure the radar signals, and measuring surface roughness in the field is time-consuming and impractical at a regional scale, leading to potential inaccuracies.

Judgmental.Question: How can the integration of satellite remote sensing and ground-based observations enhance the accuracy of land surface heat flux measurements in arid environments?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of satellite remote sensing, like ASTER data, and ground-based observations, such as those from the eddy covariance technique, can enhance the accuracy of land surface heat flux measurements by providing a comprehensive view that captures both spatial and temporal variability. The SEBS algorithm evaluation demonstrates that combining these methods allows for estimating turbulent heat fluxes with acceptable accuracy, even in partially vegetated areas.

Judgmental.Question: What are the challenges of using dual-source models for estimating land surface evapotranspiration, and how might these be addressed in future research?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges of using dual-source models include the need for component surface temperatures, which are not always available from regular observations. This issue could be addressed by developing advanced retrieval techniques or using a combination of remote sensing data and ground-based measurements to improve the estimation process. Research could focus on enhancing the availability and accuracy of these temperature observations to better utilize dual-source models in operational applications.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can surface roughness and soil moisture retrieval from radar remote sensing data be optimized to account for vegetation cover and improve accuracy?
Judgmental.Answer: Optimizing surface roughness and soil moisture retrieval from radar remote sensing data in the presence of vegetation cover can be achieved by employing a two-step retrieval scheme based on AIEM. This involves using a semi-empirical relationship for roughness parameter estimation and associating it with soil moisture retrieval. Addressing the challenges posed by vegetation cover requires careful calibration and validation of models to reduce inaccuracies and improve the reliability of estimates.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the methodologies used to estimate land surface heat fluxes in cold and arid environments.
Assertion.Answer: In cold and arid environments, land surface heat fluxes can be estimated using algorithms like the Surface Energy Balance System (SEBS), which utilizes satellite observables of land surface conditions. The methodology involves comparing field observations and SEBS estimates of net radiation flux, soil heat flux, sensible heat flux, and latent heat flux over heterogeneous land surfaces.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how radar remote sensing is applied to retrieve basin-scale soil moisture, especially in areas with surface roughness.
Assertion.Answer: Radar remote sensing, particularly using synthetic aperture radar (SAR) sensors, is applied to retrieve basin-scale soil moisture by emitting pulses and analyzing backscattered echoes from illuminated areas. The retrieval process involves considering surface roughness as it significantly influences radar backscattering. Advanced models like AIEM are used to improve accuracy by taking into account absolute phase terms and employing multi-angular radar images to deduce surface roughness parameters.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methodologies used for collecting eddy covariance flux data in agricultural settings and discuss the potential challenges faced in such environments.
Request/Directive.Answer: Eddy covariance flux data in agricultural settings can be collected using instruments set at specific heights, such as 2.81m above ground, to measure variables like wind speed, temperature, and CO2 concentration. Challenges include ensuring the representativeness of measurements over heterogeneous land surfaces and dealing with interference from structures like windbreaks or variations in vegetation cover.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the development of dual-source models for evapotranspiration estimation and the specific challenges these models address compared to single-source models.
Request/Directive.Answer: Dual-source models for evapotranspiration estimation, such as TSEBPS, simulate heat fluxes for vegetation and soil individually, addressing challenges like the requirement for component surface temperatures. These models offer improved accuracy over single-source models by incorporating detailed physical processes, though operational use is limited by the availability of necessary observations from remote sensors.
